text: ਮੋਹਿ ਰੈਣਿ ਨ ਵਿਹਾਵੈ ਨੀਦ ਨ ਆਵੈ ਬਿਨੁ ਦੇਖੇ ਗੁਰ ਦਰਬਾਰੇ ਜੀਉ ॥੩॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: I cannot endure the night, and sleep does not come, without the Sight of the Beloved Guru's Court. ||3||

transliteration.text: mōh rain n vihāvai nīd n āvai bin dēkhē gur darabārē jīu .3.

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). The Raag’s origins are based in Punjabi Folk Music and its essence was inspired by the Majha regions traditions of ‘Ausian’; the game of waiting and yearning for the return of a loved one.The feelings evoked by this Raag have often been compared to that of a mother waiting for her child to return after a long period of separation. She has an anticipation and hope for the child’s return, although at the same moment she is painfully aware of the uncertainty of their return home. This Raag brings to life the emotion of extreme love and this is highlighted by the sorrow and anguish of separation.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

text: ਹਉ ਘੋਲੀ ਜੀਉ ਘੋਲਿ ਘੁਮਾਈ ਤਿਸੁ ਸਚੇ ਗੁਰ ਦਰਬਾਰੇ ਜੀਉ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: I am a sacrifice, my soul is a sacrifice, to that True Court of the Beloved Guru. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: hau ghōlī jīu ghōl ghumāī tis sachē gur darabārē jīu .1. rahāu .

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). The Raag’s origins are based in Punjabi Folk Music and its essence was inspired by the Majha regions traditions of ‘Ausian’; the game of waiting and yearning for the return of a loved one.The feelings evoked by this Raag have often been compared to that of a mother waiting for her child to return after a long period of separation. She has an anticipation and hope for the child’s return, although at the same moment she is painfully aware of the uncertainty of their return home. This Raag brings to life the emotion of extreme love and this is highlighted by the sorrow and anguish of separation.

section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: By good fortune, I have met the Saint Guru.

section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: I have found the Immortal Lord within the home of my own self.

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). text: ਸੇਵ ਕਰੀ ਪਲੁ ਚਸਾ ਨ ਵਿਛੁੜਾ ਜਨ ਨਾਨਕ ਦਾਸ ਤੁਮਾਰੇ ਜੀਉ ॥੪॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: I will now serve You forever, and I shall never be separated from You, even for an instant. Servant Nanak is Your slave, O Beloved Master. ||4||

transliteration.text: sēv karī pal chasā n vishurā jan nānak dās tumārē jīu .4.

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). text: ਹਉ ਘੋਲੀ ਜੀਉ ਘੋਲਿ ਘੁਮਾਈ ਜਨ ਨਾਨਕ ਦਾਸ ਤੁਮਾਰੇ ਜੀਉ ॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥੧॥੮॥
section: Majh - Shabad Hazaaray (Worth A Thousand Hymns)

translation.text: I am a sacrifice, my soul is a sacrifice; servant Nanak is Your slave, Lord. ||Pause||1||8||

transliteration.text: hau ghōlī jīu ghōl ghumāī jan nānak dās tumārē jīu . rahāu .1.8.

translation.text: Raag Maajh, Fifth Mehl:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ਸਾ ਰੁਤਿ ਸੁਹਾਵੀ ਜਿਤੁ ਤੁਧੁ ਸਮਾਲੀ ॥

translation.text: Sweet is that season when I remember You.

transliteration.text: sā rut suhāvī jit tudh samālī .

text: ਸੋ ਕੰਮੁ ਸੁਹੇਲਾ ਜੋ ਤੇਰੀ ਘਾਲੀ ॥

translation.text: Sublime is that work which is done for You.

transliteration.text: sō kanm suhēlā jō tērī ghālī .

text: ਸੋ ਰਿਦਾ ਸੁਹੇਲਾ ਜਿਤੁ ਰਿਦੈ ਤੂੰ ਵੁਠਾ ਸਭਨਾ ਕੇ ਦਾਤਾਰਾ ਜੀਉ ॥੧॥

translation.text: Blessed is that heart in which You dwell, O Giver of all. ||1||

transliteration.text: sō ridā suhēlā jit ridai tūn vuthā sabhanā kē dātārā jīu .1.

text: ਜਿਸੁ ਤੂੰ ਦੇਹਿ ਸੁ ਤ੍ਰਿਪਤਿ ਅਘਾਵੈ ਸੋਈ ਭਗਤੁ ਤੁਮਾਰਾ ਜੀਉ ॥੨॥

translation.text: Those unto whom You give are satisfied and fulfilled; they become Your devotees, Lord. ||2||

transliteration.text: jis tūn dēh s tripat aghāvai sōī bhagat tumārā jīu .2.

text: ਸਭੇ ਸਾਝੀਵਾਲ ਸਦਾਇਨਿ ਤੂੰ ਕਿਸੈ ਨ ਦਿਸਹਿ ਬਾਹਰਾ ਜੀਉ ॥੩॥

translation.text: All share in Your Grace; none are beyond You. ||3||

transliteration.text: sabhē sājhīvāl sadāin tūn kisai n disah bāharā jīu .3.

text: ਨਾਨਕ ਦਾਸ ਤੇਰੈ ਬਲਿਹਾਰੈ ਸਭੁ ਤੇਰਾ ਖੇਲੁ ਦਸਾਹਰਾ ਜੀਉ ॥੪॥੨॥੯॥

text: ਸਹਜ ਗੁਫਾ ਮਹਿ ਤਾੜੀ ਲਾਈ ਆਸਣੁ ਊਚ ਸਵਾਰਿਆ ਜੀਉ ॥੧॥

translation.text: In the cave of intuitive wisdom I sit, absorbed in the silent trance of the Primal Void. I have obtained my seat in the heavens. ||1||

transliteration.text: sahaj guphā mah tārī lāī āsan ūch savāriā jīu .1.

melody.description: Raag Majh was composed by the Fifth Sikh Guru (Shri Guru Arjun Dev ji). The Raag’s origins are based in Punjabi Folk Music and its essence was inspired by the Majha regions traditions of ‘Ausian’; the game of waiting and yearning for the return of a loved one.The feelings evoked by this Raag have often been compared to that of a mother waiting for her child to return after a long period of separation. She has an anticipation and hope for the child’s return, although at the same moment she is painfully aware of the uncertainty of their return home. This Raag brings to life the emotion of extreme love and this is highlighted by the sorrow and anguish of separation.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:

text: ਫਿਰਿ ਘਿਰਿ ਅਪੁਨੇ ਗ੍ਰਿਹ ਮਹਿ ਆਇਆ ॥

translation.text: After wandering through many other homes and houses, I have returned to my own home,

transliteration.text: phir ghir apunē grih mah āiā .

translation.text: and I have found what I was longing for.

text: ਤ੍ਰਿਪਤਿ ਅਘਾਇ ਰਹਿਆ ਹੈ ਸੰਤਹੁ ਗੁਰਿ ਅਨਭਉ ਪੁਰਖੁ ਦਿਖਾਰਿਆ ਜੀਉ ॥੨॥

translation.text: I am satisfied and fulfilled; O Saints, the Guru has shown me the Fearless Lord God. ||2||

transliteration.text: tripat aghāi rahiā hai santah gur anabhau purakh dikhāriā jīu .2.

text: ਆਪੇ ਤਖਤਿ ਬਹੈ ਸਚੁ ਨਿਆਈ ਸਭ ਚੂਕੀ ਕੂਕ ਪੁਕਾਰਿਆ ਜੀਉ ॥੩॥

translation.text: He Himself sits on the throne of true justice, answering the cries and prayers of all. ||3||

transliteration.text: āpē takhat bahai sach niāī sabh chūkī kūk pukāriā jīu .3.

text: ਤਿਸੁ ਰਸੁ ਆਇਆ ਜਿਨਿ ਭੇਦੁ ਲਹਿਆ ॥

translation.text: This Sublime Essence comes only to one who knows the Mystery of the Lord.

transliteration.text: tis ras āiā jin bhēd lahiā .

text: ਜੋਤੀ ਜੋਤਿ ਮਿਲੀ ਸੁਖੁ ਪਾਇਆ ਜਨ ਨਾਨਕ ਇਕੁ ਪਸਾਰਿਆ ਜੀਉ ॥੪॥੩॥੧੦॥

translation.text: His light merges into the Light, and he finds peace. O servant Nanak, this is all the Extension of the One. ||4||3||10||

transliteration.text: jōtī jōt milī sukh pāiā jan nānak ik pasāriā jīu .4.3.10.

text: ਅਨਦ ਬਿਨੋਦ ਤਿਤੈ ਘਰਿ ਸੋਹਹਿ ਜੋ ਧਨ ਕੰਤਿ ਸਿਗਾਰੀ ਜੀਉ ॥੧॥

translation.text: Joy and celebrations decorate that house, in which the Husband Lord has adorned His soul-bride. ||1||

transliteration.text: anad binōd titai ghar sōhah jō dhan kant sigārī jīu .1.

translation.text: She is beautiful, wise, and clever. That soul-bride is the beloved of her Husband Lord. ||2||

text: ਸਾ ਕੁਲਵੰਤੀ ਸਾ ਸਭਰਾਈ ਜੋ ਪਿਰਿ ਕੈ ਰੰਗਿ ਸਵਾਰੀ ਜੀਉ ॥੩॥

translation.text: She is from a most respected family; she is the queen, adorned with the Love of her Husband Lord. ||3||

transliteration.text: sā kulavantī sā sabharāī jō pir kai rang savārī jīu .3.

translation.text: Her glory cannot be described;

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.
